channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Openreach axes connection fees for low-income homes
item.description: The network provider will not charge firms for connecting unwaged universal credit claimants.

item.title: Cookie banners: G7 urged to consider solution to pop-up notices
item.description: Information commissioner Elizabeth Denham believes the issue needs to be solved collectively.

item.title: Chinese social media site Weibo suspends 22 K-pop accounts
item.description: The social media site says 22 fan accounts have been suspended for "irrational celebrity supportâ€.

item.title: Tripwire boss steps down over support for Texas abortion law
item.description: Tripwire boss John Gibson had said he was "proud" of the Supreme Court ruling on Texas abortion.

item.title: Fear and excitement in El Salvador as Bitcoin becomes legal tender
item.description: Millions of Salvadorians are expected to download a digital wallet app with $30 of free Bitcoin.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Kim Kardashian crypto ad singled out by financial watchdog
item.description: An Instagram ad by the influencer was criticised in a speech by FCA chairman Charles Randell.

item.title: Bolsonaro: New bill will limit tech giants' power to remove content
item.description: Brazil's president signs a decree requiring firms to provide "just cause" before removing posts.

item.title: Chip shortage could last into 2023, says car boss
item.description: The car industry must learn from the Covid "stress test", says Mercedes-Benz-owner Daimler.

item.title: Netflix to continue with BBFC age ratings after successful trial
item.description: The streaming giant and the regulator will work together long term after a successful trial.

item.title: Facebook apology as AI labels black men 'primates'
item.description: The company says it was an "unacceptable error" and disabled the feature and launched an investigation.

item.title: Meet Digit, the workplace robot, and other news
item.description: BBC Click's Marc Cieslak looks at the best of the week's technology news.

item.title: Breast cancer: The AI tool trained to spot the disease
item.description: Artificial intelligence trained to spot the disease is tested at Nottingham University Hospital.

item.title: Little penguin feeding behaviour revealed with trackers
item.description: Ten males were fitted with sensors in the breeding season to give greater insight into the birds.

item.title: Gadget reviews: Smart cool boxes and neck fans
item.description: Lara Lewington looks at some of the latest gadgets to help make the most of your summer.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds: Video games and the making of Free Guy
item.description: Actor and producer Ryan Reynolds on preparing to play a character caught up in a multiplayer game.

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: How to back up your data and keep it safe
item.description: Experts recommend using three drives to back up your data and using cloud-based services.

item.title: Can apps move the #MeToo movement forward?
item.description: Reporting sexual harassment at work is getting easier thanks to new technologies.

item.title: Why is there a chip shortage?
item.description: The big chip crunch is really biting now, leaving even the most unexpected industries in crisis.

item.title: Why phone scams are so difficult to tackle
item.description: Phone fraud, both via calls and text messages, has soared during the pandemic.

item.title: How virtual reality can help to recruit and train staff
item.description: VR headsets are making a leap from fun gimmick to serious tool for firms' workforce management.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.
